Again revising down to increase the probabilities of the first two bins and lower that of the last three bins.  Over 75% of measles cases in the U.S. have occurred in New York [1]. Two NY counties, Rockland and Kings (Brooklyn), have born the brunt of measles cases.  A measles outbreak is declared over when two incubation periods for measles (42 days) have passed. On September 3rd, the outbreak in Brooklyn was declared over [2], and just yesterday the one in Rockland was also declared over [3]. This, combined with the fact that no new reported cases have emerged from the two most recent cases in York County, PA and Long Island, NY, suggests that it is very unlikely that there will be many more cases for the rest of the year - especially now that the peak measles season has passed. [1] https://www.cdc.gov/measles/cases-outbreaks.html
[2] https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2019/09/03/new-york-city-declares-end-largest-measles-outbreak-nearly-years/
[3] https://www.lohud.com/story/news/local/rockland/2019/09/24/rockland-measles-outbreak-2019-over/2432154001/

CDC added two new cases, but reconsidered 2 past cases to be false positives.  That shows a possibility of more of that happening in the future - awareness of the measles outbreak (actually, of any outbreak) leads to rush to report false positives as positives. That is because (most probably) reporting from regions is based on clinical symptoms of the disease. But then CDC confirms the clinical diagnosis with testing patient blood and/or urine for IgM antibodies to measles virus (IgM is tested because it is early indicator of infection compared to more prevalent IgG, which can be indicator of immunity from past infection or vaccination rather than new infection). October to December usually show increase in new cases, which is very common for other viral infections as well due to huddling of people together at colder weather. But with the push to vaccinate, this may be much less this year than before.  If the trickle of new cases dries up and some past positives reconsidered as false (should be not many as CDC tests samples promptly as they come - it is the regions that can procrastinate with sending these samples in), it does revive possibility of less than 1250 cases for a year, though small.

Through 9/19/19 the CDC reports a national measles case count of 1,241. Extrapolating linearly, expected case count would be 1,729, though given the profile of cases reported over time, this seems like an overestimate of the median outcome. Given the clustering of cases on additional outbreaks, I expect the tail to be quite fat relative to a normal distribution. https://www.cdc.gov/measles/cases-outbreaks.html

For a number of reasons we can expect to observe a material slowdown in cases per month. First, measles requires tropical / warm weather to spread and so late Q3 and early Q4 are seasonally the weakest. We can observe this in WHO data (which gives us seasonality by month for a few countries going back many years) - this isn't perfect because some of these countries are in different hemisphere but hopefully it is good enough. Also, 2014 (past peak measles) going into 2015 we saw a 75% drop in cases (simply because of reversion to the mean), so we should expect a slowdown in cases for that reason too. Finally, we are already seeing a slowdown in cases per month because case / month has dropped by about 25 since June. We also get Sep to date data from WHO so you can guess what rest of september will be for purposes of analysis. What worries me is that the rate of slow-down was lower in September (e.g., CDC partial-month number in Sep implies 30 for Sep vs. 24 in Aug), which causes me to expand my bounds upward a bit.

The outbreak in New York is reported to be over (1), it was mainly spread in communities with pockets of unvaccinated people. https://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/917107 "Current Texas schools' vaccination rates could allow for measles outbreaks as large as 400 cases in the Dallas-Fort Worth and Austin metropolitan areas, according to a study published online today in JAMA Network Open.
. . . 
"Nonmedical exemption rates in Texas have been increasing every year since 2003, when state legislation made it easier to obtain nonmedical exemptions. In fact, exemptions have increased 28-fold, from 2300 in 2003 to 64,000 in
2018 . . . " "Texas is the largest state by population that allows vaccine exemptions for religious or personal reasons," . . . The researchers used 2010 US Census data to create a model to simulate possible measles transmissions in the Texas population. The model incorporated 2018 vaccination rates for Texas schools and typical daily activities and interactions for 1000 simulations in each metropolitan area of the state. Each hypothetical scenario tracked infections over 9 months. They estimate that the median number of cases in Texas cities would likely range from 1 to 3 cases if 2018 vaccination rates are maintained during an outbreak, which is in line with case numbers seen in outbreaks that occurred between 2006 and 2017. However, the number of cases could climb above 400 in the Austin and Dallas-Fort Worth metro areas, according to the model's upper limit predictions. That number of cases would rival the largest outbreaks since US measles elimination in 2000. The combination of high population density and multiple undervaccinated schools would drive these outbreaks, the authors note. Specifically, 35 schools in Austin-Round Rock, 13 schools in Dallas-Fort Worth, and 15 schools in Tyler have vaccination rates below the estimated herd immunity lower threshold of 92%. When the researchers investigated the effects of even lower immunization rates than seen in 2018 — if existing trends were to continue in currently undervaccinated schools — they found exponentially greater outbreaks. For example, a 5% reduction in immunizations was correlated with a 40% to 4000% larger outbreak than would be seen with the 2018 vaccination rate, depending on the city.  The model estimates that 64% of those infected would be students whose parents had refused vaccination, whereas the other 36% cases would be "bystanders," such as individuals too young or too ill to be vaccinated, those in whom the vaccine is contraindicated, and those in whom the vaccine had waned or was ineffective. The authors noted that even small networks could have big impacts, such as two schools in Tyler, Texas, whose vaccination rates are 70% and 85%. "In the event of an outbreak in schools with undervaccinated populations, interventions targeted at these schools may be especially effective," Sinclair and colleagues write. "Undervaccinated close-knit communities present an increased risk of outbreaks; mandating that schools with low vaccination rates plan for outbreak scenarios may help reduce outbreak sizes." This one was difficult to work through.  I took inspiration from dglid's approach and pulled down the WHO measles cases and averaged the individual and cumulative proportions of cases observed for North America, and much of Western Europe.  I used this to get a general time trend for the cumulative proportions per month and then worked out an empirical distribution for July cumulative proportions of cases (5th, 50th, and 95th percentiles were .4%, 80%, and ~98%, respectively).  I then used the current US cases for the year (1148 as of yesterday) and ran 250 Monte Carlo deviates from the above empiric distribution (ie, 1148/rand-dist).  I finally took the logs of these results because of the obvious right skew and used a log normal distribution to calculate the results I posted.  My geometric mean came out to be about 1480 with 10th and 90th Percentile values of 1195 and 2016, respectively

There are a lot of variables to consider - healthcare professionals are raising the alarm (but they have been doing so for years), both govt and private orgs are stepping in for some cases (tightening rules that allow parents to skip vaccination for school or summer camp, for example), misinformation about vaccines is still being spread, and anti-vaxx parents are organizing to get around the rules, just to name a few. I've conservatively raised [0, 1,250] by 6% to 28% but will continue to monitor. My estimated range is comfortably below 1,500; raising the probability of (1,250, 1,500) by 15% to 60%. Reaching 1,500 would require some of the following events that we have not seen in recent years:
- Unseasonally high late summer cases
- An unusually high spike in November and December (leading into a second consecutive high year for measles)
- Unusually high penetration into the unvaccinated population
- Unusually high penetration into the vaccinated population (you can still get the measles if vaccinated, though very very unlikely and usually very mild) While one or two of those may occur, it is very unlikely that we will see +250 cases over the above estimate in the back half of the year. I place that at notably lower than 1 in 10, lowering it to 8%. To reach 1,750, virtually all of the above events would have to occur plus some additional that have not been considered. As it is exceedingly unlikely, I have dropped this to 3%. For 2000+ in the case that we see some catastrophe that leads us to 1750+ (as that would require more than simple incremental cases on our current trajectory), I would say it is a 1 in 4 chance that this catastrophe would lead us to 2000+ cases. 1% overall probability.

One ought to consider the seasonality of measles contraction, as documented in the academic literature [1,2,3]. Here, I quantify seasonality as relative distance from the January-June average. The CDC reported 1,109 cases up until end of June [5], which equates to an average monthly value of 185. I calculate seasonality using incidence data from [3] for Michigan and taking the second year in the first figure, which looks the most representative out of all of them. After extracting the data, this implies the following seasonal factors (the percentages are percent of the average January-June value). July	99%
August	86%
September	52%
October	39%
November	43%
December	47% Applying these percentages to the historical 2019 data, I estimate the following number of cases: July	182
August	159
September	95
October	71
November	79
December	87 The total for the year then is 1,771. However, it's worth noting that the estimated July value is higher than the actual June value, which is quite unusual in light of historical data. It's therefore quite possible that this model overestimates the number of cases. As an alternative case, I use the Google Search results for measles from [3] to estimate seasonal factors. This results in a total of 1,812. Therefore, I skew my distribution up very slightly. [1] https://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article/file?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1007327&type=printable

As of 27 July 2019, there are 1095 cases in the US. A naive approach of estimating 1100 cases over 6 months will repeat in the next 6 months suggests 2200 cases in 2019. This does not account for seasonality, regional outbreaks, or regional efforts by health professionals and legislators to curb infection. Even in the best case, it is extremely unlikely that efforts to curb infection will be so successful that infections will remain under 1250. Similarly, it is highly unlikely that the current CDC estimate is off so significantly that the final count for the year will be under 1250. Leading to a ~1% probability. A similar argument suggests that it is more probable, but still unlikely that 2019 sees <1500 breakouts (~6%) While it is still unknown what impact will have been made, I believe redoubled efforts to educate about vaccination coupled with schools and summer camps tightening down on vaccination requirements will improve the start of measle season this fall compared to the end of the season this past spring. (40-43%, I actually anticipate the 1700-1800 range, giving a slight edge to the higher end) Because of the naive estimate being well over 2000 for 2019, I gave a significantly higher probability to the upper-end estimate than the lower. Using the CDC website the monthly figures for measles cases were: Jan 52, Feb 154, Mar 181, Apr 317 and May 275. Figure for the week to June 6 was 41. Extrapolating this value then the figure for June would be around 175. From this it looks like the rate of infection is decreasing substantially.
Looking at more detail where the outbreaks are, the CDC indicate that ongoing outbreaks (defined as at least 3 people affected) are happening in New York State (2 places), California (3 places), Pennsylvania and Washington state.  
Looking at figures for these states (from the CDC link to the state health authorities) it seems that the main outbreak in Washington is over, but in May six people were affected in a different part of Washington state which could signify a new outbreak starting.  How bad this will be will depend upon how well the outbreak can be contained and whether it hits a large community of unvaccinated people like the New York outbreaks did.
I couldn't find much info for Penn state, but New York City's data shows that the rate of infection is tailing off (Jan 34, Feb 69, Mar 160, Apr 177, May 86).  New York has had a very aggressive containment policy including mandatory vaccination and this seems to be curtailing spread of the disease and will probably continue to do so, especially if people in neighbouring areas who are unvaccinated decide that the risk is high and they should get vaccinated.  
The outbreaks in California were much smaller (Jan 4, Feb 2, Mar 14, Apr 21, May 7) but still show the same type of distribution as the NYC and the overall figures, namely that the rate of infection increased significantly in March, increased yet further in April and then decreased noticeably in May. 
It seems to me that there will most likely be fewer cases in June than in May, and this downward trend may well continue.  I heard that spring is the peak time for measles, at least in Europe, and think that it would be similar for the US but haven't fact checked this.  If this is the case, then we would expect the number of new cases to tail off significantly over the summer and into early autumn.  Having said that, there are usually more people travelling in the summer who could potentially catch measles abroad and bring it back to the US, and the CDC indicated that most of the outbreaks started with people bringing measles into the US from trips abroad.
From the data on the 2014 outbreak in the US (thanks cafebedouin for providing the link to the weekly tables) it seems that the number of new cases tails off very rapidly once the infection is past its peak.
Assuming that (i) there is no new large NYC style outbreak in an unvaccinated community, and (ii) measles is more prevalent in the spring, then I would expect the total number to be below 1500 by the end of the year.

The key piece of data you need for this question is from National Notifiable Infectious Diseases: Weekly Tables, where it will tell you indigenous and imported measles infections for the current week, which are 2 and 5 or 7 total for week 22. Go back to previous weeks 21, 20, and 19 for the current rolling month to date, the totals are 12, 32, and 9 or 60 for the most recent 4 week period. To get previous weeks just change the two 22s in the web address to the week of interest.[1] If you look at this forecast some time in the future, the current week can be found at the Wonder weekly table website (under Malaria; Measles):
https://wonder.cdc.gov/nndss/nndss_weekly_tables_menu.asp This suggests to me that we are going to see a sizable drop from  52, 154, 181, 317, 275 of January through May in June.
